Read the full story, âAfrican Agro-Processors Call for Policies Conducive to Local Manufacturingâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: African Agro-Processors Call for Policies Conducive to Local Manufacturing

articles.description:
LONDON, Sep 15 (IPS) - With hope and courage, we must rise to the challenges before us. We must rise to the challenge of a world set afire by climate change, forced displacement, armed conflicts and human rights abuses. We must rise to the challenge of girls being denied their right to an education in Afghanistan. We must rise to the challenge of a global refugee crisis that is disrupting development gains the world over. We must rise to the challenge of brutal and unconscionable wars in places like Sudan and Ukraine that are putting millions of children at risk every day.

Read the full story, âThe Vast Potential of the Human Spiritâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: The Vast Potential of the Human Spirit

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Sep 15 (IPS) - The General Assembly and ECOSOC Affairs Division has around 40 staff members, with the combined role to facilitate the deliberations and decision-making of intergovernmental bodies such as the General Assembly and the Economic and Social Council and their subsidiary organs.

Read the full story, âHow a UN General Assembly Meeting is Organizedâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: How a UN General Assembly Meeting is Organized

articles.description:
The UN World Health Organization (WHO) on Friday joined with the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, to underline the critical importance of preserving the dignity of the dead in the wake of recent natural disasters in Libya and Morocco.

Read the full story, âPreserving dignity, public health: Managing deceased bodies during crisesâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Preserving dignity, public health: Managing deceased bodies during crises

articles.description:
Societies must engage meaningfully with young people and empower them with the skills and education they need as the standard bearers of democratic principles, Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres said, commemorating the International Day of Democracy, on Friday.

Read the full story, âEmpower youth to safeguard democracy: Guterresâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Empower youth to safeguard democracy: Guterres

articles.description:
Saudi Arabia must immediately revoke the death sentence handed down to Mohammed Al Ghamdi for posting critical views online, as the crackdown on freedom of expression in the country continues to escalate, independent UN human rights experts said on Friday.

Read the full story, âTime to revoke death penalty for social media dissent, UN experts urgeâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Time to revoke death penalty for social media dissent, UN experts urge

articles.description:
MEXICO CITYhttps://ipsnoticias.net/2023/09/mexico-gira-hacia-los-militares-empresarios/, Sep 14 (IPS) - Courage, sadness and impotence are expressed by Mayan indigenous activist Sara LÃ³pez when she talks about the Mayan Train (TM), the Mexican government's biggest infrastructure project, which will cross the town where she lives and many others in the Yucatan Peninsula.

Read the full story, âMexico Turns to Military Entrepreneursâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Mexico Turns to Military Entrepreneurs

articles.description:
WASHINGTON DC, Sep 14 (IPS) - Another UNGA (UN General Assembly High-Level Week, September 18-23, 2023) is almost here. Leaders and other senior representatives of the world bodyâs 193 Member States will gather again for this truly one-of-a-kind annual congregation in New York for high-stakes diplomacy and plenty of domestic political posturing.

Read the full story, âSix Issues to Watch at the UN General Assembly 78â, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Six Issues to Watch at the UN General Assembly 78

articles.description:
Addressing the Security Council on Thursday, the head of the World Food Programme (WFP), Cindy McCain, highlighted the growing need for humanitarian aid worldwide against a backdrop of reduced funding.

Read the full story, ââThriving economiesâ critical to eradicating hunger and poverty: McCainâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: âThriving economiesâ critical to eradicating hunger and poverty: McCain

articles.description:
One year since the nationwide protests in the aftermath of death in custody of Mahsa Amini, harassment of women and girls by Iranian authorities are on the rise, an independent UN investigative body said on Thursday.

Read the full story, âIran: Harassment, reprisals continue for Mahsa Aminiâs familyâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Iran: Harassment, reprisals continue for Mahsa Aminiâs family

articles.description:
UN humanitarians are working flat out on the ground in Libya, providing desperately needed aid to thousands of survivors of the flood disaster that has left thousands dead and thousands more unaccounted for.

Read the full story, âUN launches flash appeal to aid 250,000 Libyans hit by devastating floodsâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: UN launches flash appeal to aid 250,000 Libyans hit by devastating floods

articles.description:
UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres on Thursday reiterated his call to action for countries across the world to establish peace forged through sustainable development, human rights and a healthy environment.

Read the full story, ââPeace begins with youâ, youth activist tells UN forumâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: âPeace begins with youâ, youth activist tells UN forum

articles.description:
Endurance swimmer Lewis Pugh traded the ocean for New York Stateâs Hudson River, declaring at the end of his epic 517 kilometre journey downriver on Wednesday that âwe can never become complacent when it comes to protecting the environmentâ.

Read the full story, âEnvironmental champion hails rivers as âarteries of our planetââ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Environmental champion hails rivers as âarteries of our planetâ

articles.description:
The SDG Summit, taking place at the start of the UN General Assembly High Level Week, marks halftime for the crucial Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

Read the full story, âUN marks halftime for the SDGsâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: UN marks halftime for the SDGs

articles.description:
Insufficient progress towards climate goals is slowing down the global fight against poverty, hunger and deadly diseases, according to a report released on Thursday by the UN World Meteorological Organization (WMO).

Read the full story, âClimate inaction puts lives on the line: WMOâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Climate inaction puts lives on the line: WMO

articles.description:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sep 13 (IPS) - On 26 August, Gabon went through the motions of an election. Official results were announced four days later, in the middle of the night, with the country under curfew. Predictably, incumbent President Ali Bongo, in power since the death of his father and predecessor in 2009, was handed a third term. Fraud allegations were rife, as in previous elections. But this time something unprecedented happened: less than an hour later the military had taken over, and the Bongo familyâs 56-year reign had ended.

Read the full story, âGabon: The End of a Dictatorship and the Beginning of Another?â, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Gabon: The End of a Dictatorship and the Beginning of Another?

articles.description:
GWADAR, Pakistan, Sep 13 (IPS) - Ten years ago I ran an academy for girls in Dohr Gatti, a small slum on the outskirts of Gwadar, a coastal city in Balochistan, southwestern Pakistan.Â Most of the girls were between the ages of eleven and fifteen and had the little opportunity to receive a formal education.

Read the full story, âThe Baloch Girls Remain Stranded at the School Gatesâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: The Baloch Girls Remain Stranded at the School Gates

articles.description:
BUDGAM, INDIA, Sep 13 (IPS) - It has been over a decade since 32-year-old Rafiqa (not her real name) was sold to a villager after being lured by the promise that she would be employed in the handicrafts industry of Indian-administered Kashmir.

Read the full story, âHuman Trafficking: Women Lured by Promise of Jobs, Sold as Bridesâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Human Trafficking: Women Lured by Promise of Jobs, Sold as Brides

articles.description:
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sep 13 (IPS) - The commodity boom early this century was mainly driven by mineral prices. Yet, miningâs contribution to developing countriesâ revenue has been modest, largely due to massive tax evasion and avoidance.

Read the full story, âEnhancing Mining Revenueâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: Enhancing Mining Revenue

articles.description:
OAKLAND, California, Sep 13 (IPS) - In the wake of the recent Africa Climate Summit, which convened in Nairobi from September 4-6, 2023, the worldâs attention was drawn to the pressing challenges facing the African continent as it grapples with the devastating effects of climate change.

Read the full story, âThe Africa Climate Summit: Anti-Colonial Rhetoric Meets Green Colonialismâ, on globalissues.org â
articles.title: The Africa Climate Summit: Anti-Colonial Rhetoric Meets Green Colonialism

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
EXPERT PERSPECTIVE â Today, as Western pundits and military experts monitor progress of the Ukrainian counteroffensive against Russiaâs occupation forces in Southern Ukraine, many correctly [...] More 
The post The Argument for Adopting a Reagan Strategy in Ukraine appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: The Argument for Adopting a Reagan Strategy in Ukraine
Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan
Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: Apple pledged on Friday to update software on iPhone 12s in France to settle a row over radiation levels, but concerns in other European countries signalled it may have to take similar action elsewhere. France this week suspended sales of iPhone 12 handsets after tests which it said found breaches of radiation exposure limits.
articles.title: Apple to update iPhone 12 in France after radiation row

articles.description: Iran has seized two oil tankers allegedly carrying smuggled fuel in the Gulf and arrested their crews, state television announced on Friday. "The Revolutionary Guards naval forces seized two ships over the course of the last two days," state television said, citing Mohammad-Sharif Shirali, a Guards commander. "
articles.title: Iran seizes two foreign tankers for 'smuggling'

articles.description: Libyan authorities limited access to an inundated city on Friday to allow searchers to dig through mud and hollowed-out buildings for 10,000 people missing and feared dead in flooding that has already killed more than 11,000. Authorities warned that disease and explosives shifted by the waters could claim yet more lives.
articles.title: Search teams look for 10,000 missing in flooded Libyan city after toll tops 11,000

articles.description: In the midst of the 1979 Iran hostage crisis, the CIA began what came to be noted as one of the spy agency's most successful publicly known operations: the rescue of six American diplomats who had escaped the overrun US embassy - using a fake movie as the cover story.
articles.title: Ben Affleck played lone hero in 'Argo'. CIA now reveals identity of 2nd spy in op

articles.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy  will visit Washington next week to solidify support from the US in fighting Russian invaders. Zelenskyy will meet with President Joe Biden and hold meetings at the US Congress. The visit comes at a critical time as Ukraine wages a counteroffensive against Russia. Biden will reaffirm his commitment to supporting Ukraine's independence and territorial integrity.
articles.title: Zelensky to make second wartime White House visit to rally support

articles.description: The Dominican Republic shut all land, air and sea borders with Haiti on Friday in a dispute about construction of a canal on Haitian soil that taps into a shared river, as armed Dominican soldiers patrolled entry points and military planes roared overhead.
articles.title: Dominican Republic closes all borders with Haiti as tensions rise in a dispute over a canal

articles.description: Federal prosecutors are seeking an order that would prevent Donald Trump from making âinflammatoryâ and âintimidatingâ comments about witnesses, lawyers and other people involved in the criminal case charging the former president with scheming to overturn the 2020 presidential election.
articles.title: Prosecutors seek narrow gag order on Trump in DC elections case after 'inflammatory' public comments

articles.description: Pakistan on Friday announced a record rise in petrol and diesel prices, the second big increase in two weeks for the South Asian nation that is already struggling with high inflation.
articles.title: Pakistan raises petrol, diesel prices by record amount

articles.description: The Kasbah La Dame Bija guesthouse in Morocco's picturesque Ouirgane Valley escaped unscathed from an earthquake that devastated the area, but the owner's bookings collapsed and he worries about whether the region can revive its tourist appeal.
articles.title: Moroccans in earthquake-hit tourist area grieve losses, fret about future

articles.description: KABUL: The Taliban have detained 18 staffers, including a foreigner, from a nongovernmental organisation based in Afghanistan, the nonprofit group sai.
articles.title: Taliban have detained 18 staff, including a foreigner, from an Afghanistan-based NGO, it says

articles.description: President Joe Biden has announced new sanctions on individuals in Iran responsible for human rights abuses, as the US marks the anniversary of the death of Mahsa Amini. Amini died while in police custody after being detained for allegedly wearing her hijab too loosely.
articles.title: Biden announces more Iran sanctions on the anniversary of Mahsa Amini's death

articles.description: The United Nations' World Heritage Committee has added two historical sites in Ukraine to its list of endangered sites. The St. Sophia Cathedral in Kyiv and the medieval center of Lviv are UNESCO World Heritage Sites that are important to Ukraine's culture and history. While neither site has been directly targeted in the ongoing conflict with Russia, the decision to list them as endangered could help deter further attacks.
articles.title: UNESCO puts 2 locations in war-ravaged Ukraine on its list of historic sites in danger

articles.description: Lampedusa, an Italian island nestled in the Mediterranean between Tunisia, Malta, and the larger Sicilian island, is grappling with an unprecedented migrant crisis. ââââIn the span of a week, approximately 7,000 migrants have arrived, surpassing the island's permanent residents and straining its capacity to provide adequate assistance.
articles.title: Why are Italians upset with Giorgia Meloni

articles.description: A group of would-be protesters in Sarajevo are shouting and blowing whistles at the EU force's camp, in a demonstration reminiscent of recent protests by Bosnian Serbs. The EUFOR is currently conducting an exercise called "Quick Response 2023" to test its ability to rapidly activate and integrate reserve troops. The commander of EUFOR, Helmut Habermayer, emphasized the importance of adapting forces in volatile times, but also stated that military force is always the last resort.
articles.title: EU troops confront would-be rioters in exercise echoing Bosnia political crisis

articles.description: Lithuania's President Gitanas Nauseda has revoked retired Olympic figure skater Margarita Drobiazko's Lithuanian citizenship due to her support for Russia. Drobiazko, who was born in Moscow and represented Lithuania in five Olympic Games, has been accused of breaking her oath and discrediting Lithuania by cooperating with Russia. Last year, Nauseda also stripped Drobiazko and her partner of Lithuanian state decoration after they performed in a skating show in Russia.
articles.title: Lithuania strips citizenship from retired Olympic ice skater for support for Russia

articles.description: Iranian security forces have been deployed in the hometown of Mahsa Amini ahead of the first anniversary of her death in police custody, according to witnesses and rights groups. Amini's death sparked widespread anti-government protests, with over 500 people killed and thousands arrested. Security forces have reportedly been stationed in several cities, and surveillance cameras have been installed to monitor potential protesters. Internet connectivity has also been disrupted in some areas.
articles.title: Heavy security in Iran on Mahsa Amini death anniversary -rights groups, witnesses

articles.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un visited an aircraft factory in Russia, where he inspected the country's most advanced fighter jet, the Su-57. This visit has raised concerns about potential banned weapons transfer deals between the two countries. Kim's trip to Russia, which includes meetings with President Vladimir Putin and visits to weapons and technology sites, highlights the deepening ties between the two nations.
articles.title: North Korea's Kim gets a close look at Russian fighter jets as his tour narrows its focus to weapons

articles.description: The Pakistan-Afghanistan Torkham border has been reopened after eight days of closure. The decision to resume movement on the trade border was made by both countries. Tensions between the Pakistan and Afghanistan Army have subsided, allowing vehicular and foot traffic to resume. Vehicles are being allowed to cross the border after clearance, and people who were stuck for over a week are also permitted to crossover after strict inspection.
articles.title: Pakistan, Afghanistan Torkham border reopens after eight days of closure

articles.description: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has announced plans to ban American XL Bully dogs, describing them as a "danger to our communities." The breed is not currently recognized as a breed in the UK, but Sunak has asked for a legal definition to be established. The government has faced pressure to take action after recent attacks, including one in which an 11-year-old girl was seriously injured.
articles.title: After attacks, British prime minister says American XL Bully dogs are dangerous and will be banned

articles.description: Northeastern University in the US has decided to award a posthumous master's degree to Indian student Jaahnavi Kandula, who tragically died after being hit by a speeding police car. The degree will be presented to her family from Andhra Pradesh. The university's Chancellor expressed solidarity with the Indian student community and condemned the insensitive remarks made by a Seattle police officer regarding the incident.
articles.title: Indian student Jaahnavi Kandula to get master's degree posthumously

articles.description: Rescue teams have arrived from Egypt, Tunisia, the UAE, Turkiye and Qatar.
articles.title: Political fractures hinder global aid

articles.description: The coastal city of Derna in Libya experienced severe flooding after two dams burst, leaving thousands of people displaced and searching for loved ones. Many residents were caught off guard by the flooding as there were no evacuation plans in place. The devastation caused by the floodwaters resulted in the loss of lives and destruction of buildings.
articles.title: Caught unaware, whole families drowned in a matter of minutes

articles.description: Libyan authorities have called for an investigation into the cause of the devastating floods that have resulted in thousands of deaths in the country. The floods were triggered by a powerful storm that caused dams to burst, washing away buildings and trapping people inside. The death toll is estimated to be in the thousands, with many more people missing.
articles.title: Libya seeks answers as flood deaths feared to cross 20,000

articles.description: Nasa has released findings from its yearlong study into UFOs, stating that the study of these unidentified flying objects will require new scientific techniques and a shift in perception. The study's 33-page report cautions that the negative perception surrounding UFOs hampers data collection. NASA Administrator Bill Nelson aims to shift the conversation from sensationalism to science and reduce the stigma around UAPs (unidentified anomalous phenomena).
articles.title: Nasa says more science and less stigma are needed to understand UFOs

articles.description: The Pentagon has clarified that it has not restarted counterterrorism operations in Niger, despite earlier reports. Gen. James Hecker had stated that some manned aircraft and drone operations had resumed, but the Pentagon clarified that these missions were only for protecting US forces and not broader counterterrorism operations.
articles.title: Pentagon says surveillance flights, not counterterrorism ops, have restarted in Niger

articles.description: President Joe Biden challenged his Republican opponents by arguing that his management of the economy has been better than former President Donald Trump's. He accused Republicans of undermining working-class Americans and criticized their plans to cut taxes for the wealthy and make savings from Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.
articles.title: Joe Biden accuses Republicans of undercutting working-class Americans

articles.description: China conducted large-scale military drills in the Western Pacific, deploying an aircraft carrier and numerous naval ships and warplanes as a display of power against US pressure. The exercises took place after the U.S. conducted military drills with allies in the region. China's aircraft carrier, along with missile destroyers, frigates, and supply ships, were spotted in waters near Japan, Taiwan, and the Philippines.
articles.title: China conducts major military exercises in Western Pacific

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to meet Elon Musk during his upcoming trip to the United States. The meeting, scheduled for Monday, will focus on discussions about artificial intelligence. This comes as Musk faces accusations of allowing antisemitic messages on his social media platform, X. The Anti-Defamation League has accused Musk of amplifying hate speech, but Musk has denied these claims.
articles.title: Israel's Benjamin Netanyahu is to meet Elon Musk. Their sit-down comes as X faces antisemitism controversy

articles.description: China has increased its military exercises near Taiwan, scrambling 68 military aircraft and sending 10 navy vessels into the area. The Chinese fleet, including the Shandong aircraft carrier, was detected about 60 nautical miles southeast of Taiwan. China claims Taiwan as its own territory and has been pressuring the island through military and political means.
articles.title: Taiwan detects 68 Chinese warplanes, 10 Navy vessels near island

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to meet with billionaire Elon Musk during his upcoming trip to the United States. The agenda for the meeting has not been disclosed. However, Musk has recently faced accusations of allowing antisemitic messages on his social media platform, X.
articles.title: Israel's Netanyahu to meet Elon Musk as company faces antisemitism controversy

articles.description: Talks between the leaders of Serbia and Kosovo on improving ties failed to make a breakthrough Thursday, after Pristina rejected an EU compromise proposal, the bloc's foreign policy chief said. Kosovo insists it wants Serbia to make the first move by taking steps towards officially recognising its independence.
articles.title: EU fails to find breakthrough in Serbia, Kosovo talks

articles.description: The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is set to announce new restrictions on the use of artificial intelligence (AI) technology. While the agency has successfully utilized AI in drug busts and crime prevention, DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas stresses the importance of responsible and trustworthy use of AI that safeguards privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties.
articles.title: US Homeland Security Department reveals new AI guardrails as it deploys technology across agency

articles.description: The United Nations said Thursday that most of the thousands of deaths in Libya's flood disaster could have been averted if early warning and emergency management systems had functioned properly. If the system in Libya ad worked properly, "the emergency management forces would have been able to carry out the evacuation of the people, and we could have avoided most of the human casualties," WMO chief Petteri Taalas told reporters in Geneva.
articles.title: Most Libya flood casualties could have been avoided: UN

articles.description: Survivors of a migrant shipwreck off Greece in June have filed a lawsuit against the Greek authorities, accusing them of failing to protect the lives of those on board. The overcrowded fishing trawler, carrying between 400-750 people from Pakistan, Syria, and Egypt, sank in international waters. Only 104 men survived, and 82 bodies were recovered.
articles.title: Survivors of migrant shipwreck file lawsuit against Greek authorities

articles.description: A Palestinian family in Libya, who had fled Gaza during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, has been affected by the devastating floods in the country. Two members of the Abu Amra family have died, and 12 others are missing after the storm caused dams to burst and destroyed a quarter of the city of Derna.
articles.title: Palestinian family that fled wars suffers deaths in Libya

articles.description: Israel's Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich, a leader of the settlement movement, has taken steps to solidify Israel's control over the occupied West Bank. Smotrich has approved new settlement homes, legalized unauthorized outposts, and made it harder for Palestinians to build homes and move freely.
articles.title: Israel's finance minister now governs the West Bank. Critics see steps toward permanent control

articles.description: Firefighters in the United States are suing manufacturers and companies that make firefighting gear and foam, claiming that the gear contains toxic industrial compound PFAS, which is associated with health problems including cancer. Cancer has become the leading cause of death among firefighters, with the International Association of Fire Fighters attributing 66% of firefighter deaths between 2002 and 2019 to cancer.
articles.title: Firefighters fear the toxic industrial PFAS in the gear could be contributing to rising cancer cases

articles.description: Ten children were among the 56 people killed in a blaze in a Hanoi high-rise, police said on Thursday, which some residents desperately tried to escape by jumping out of upper stories, according to witnesses. Authorities have still not released the cause of the fire, which broke out just before midnight Tuesday and wasn't extinguished until Wednesday morning in the nine-story apartment building in Vietnam's capital.
articles.title: Witnesses say victims of a Hanoi high-rise fire jumped from upper stories to escape the blaze

articles.description: The city of Derna has buried thousands of people in mass graves, Libyan officials said Thursday, as search teams scoured ruins left by devastating floods and the city's mayor said that the death toll could triple or more. The deluge swept away entire families on Sunday night and exposed vulnerabilities in the oil-rich country that has been mired in conflict since its 2011 uprising.
articles.title: Libyan city buries thousands in mass graves after flood, while mayor says death toll could triple

articles.description: Taiwan has criticized Elon Musk for his comments on Taiwan being an integral part of China. The Taiwanese Foreign Ministry spokesman stated that Musk's blind flattery of China is not worthy of respect. Taiwan's foreign minister also suggested that Musk ask the Chinese Communist Party to open his platform, X, to the Chinese people.
articles.title: Taiwan slams Musk for calling it an 'integral part' of China

articles.description: Tech CEOs including Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg, and Sundar Pichai met with lawmakers to discuss AI regulation. Musk called for a US "referee" for AI to ensure safe use of the technology. Zuckerberg said Congress should engage with AI to support innovation and safeguards.
articles.title: Tech titans meet United States lawmakers, Elon Musk seeks 'referee' for artificial intelligence

articles.description: An Afghan soldier who escaped the Taliban and traveled through multiple countries before being detained at the Texas-Mexico border has been granted asylum in the United States. Abdul Wasi Safi, who feared being sent back to Afghanistan and killed by the Taliban, can now remain safely in the US
articles.title: Afghan soldier who was arrested at US-Mexico border after fleeing Taliban is granted asylum

articles.description: Brazil's high court opened the first trials Wednesday over the January 8 riots in Brasilia by supporters of far-right ex-president Jair Bolsonaro, who were demanding the ouster of his successor, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Defense attorney Sebastiao Coelho da Silva called the trial "politically motivated."
articles.title: Brazil opens first trials over January 8 riots

articles.description: In what was hailed as a âmomentousâ move by Cambodia, the late American pipeline businessman George Lindemannâs family âvoluntarilyâ agreed to return 33 looted artefacts to the Southeast Asian country. According to the US Attorney's Office, the artefacts that would be returned include statues of deities, angels and demons from the 10th and 12th centuries from Koh Ker.
articles.title: Family of late US billionaire George Lindemann agrees to return looted artefacts to Cambodia

articles.description: Vivek Ramaswamy joined a rising chorus of Republican presidential contenders in 2024 who have pledged to drastically cut the size and scope of the federal government if elected next year, calling for a "revolution" that will hold the federal bureaucracy "accountable."
articles.title: White House hopeful Ramaswamy joins Trump in calling for huge government job cuts

articles.description: White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre strongly criticized Republican plans to launch an impeachment inquiry against President Joe Biden. She denounced the effort as baseless and a political stunt, highlighting the lack of concrete evidence presented by Republicans. Jean-Pierre suggested that the initiative was driven by pressure from the far-right wing of the Republican Party and characterized the process as illegitimate.
articles.title: White House press secretary slams Republican impeachment inquiry against president Joe Biden as baseless

articles.description: A teenager in the United States was charged allegedly for trying to drown a black teen in a Cape Cod pond in Massachusetts. The black teen alleged that while John Sheeran (14) jabbed his head into the water, another white teen laughed and called him âGeorge Floydâ as he couldnât breathe.
articles.title: US teen, 14, charged of trying to drown Black youth in pond

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Pakistan President Arif Alvi has proposed November 6 as the date for the country's upcoming elections in a letter to the Chief Election Commissioner. The move has sparked controversy, as there are divided opinions among stakeholders on the timing of the polls. The president cited constitutional provisions giving him the authority to announce the poll date.
articles.title: Pakistan President Arif Alvi âadvisesâ EC to hold polls on Nov 6

articles.description: The White House denied Wednesday that the unfreezing of $6 billion of Iranian funds to help secure the release of five US citizens was effectively a ransom payment. It's not ransom," said White House national security spokesman John Kirby, pushing back against criticism of the deal.
articles.title: White House says Iran deal is 'not ransom'

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Imran Khan, the leader of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party, has had his judicial remand extended until September 26 in a cipher case. Khan and Shah Mahmood Qureshi, a former foreign minister, are accused of making public the contents of a confidential diplomatic cable. The cable was cited by Khan as proof of a US attempt to remove his government.
articles.title: Pakistan court extends Imran Khanâs remand in cipher case

articles.description: Former President Donald Trump dined with Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene and discussed the strategy for impeaching President Joe Biden. Trump has been closely following House Republicans' push for impeachment and has encouraged their efforts.Elise Stefanik, who briefed him on the impeachment inquiry strategy. However, Trump has not been pressuring House Speaker Kevin McCarthy regarding the impeachment inquiry into Biden.
articles.title: Trump has been privately encouraging GOP lawmakers to impeach Joe Biden

articles.description: Slovakia's Supreme Court has upheld a ruling dismissing a lawsuit by former Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babis against allegations of collaboration with the communist-era secret police. Babis had sued Slovakia's Institute of the Nation's Memory, which holds parts of his secret police files. The institute claims the files contain evidence that Babis was an agent, but he denies this.
articles.title: Former Czech Premier Andrej Babis loses case on collaborating with communist-era secret police

articles.description: Israeli air strikes on Wednesday killed two Syrian soldiers and wounded six others on Syria's west coast, state media said, quoting a military source. "At exactly 17:22 this afternoon, the Israeli enemy carried out strikes... from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea targeting some of our air defence sites in Tartus," the official news agency SANA quoted the source as saying.
articles.title: Israel strikes on Syria kill two soldiers: state media

articles.description: At least 5,100 people have been killed in the eastern Libyan city of Derna due to massive flooding caused by Mediterranean storm Daniel. The flooding, which was the result of two dams collapsing, has left thousands missing and tens of thousands homeless. Aid workers have struggled to reach the city due to washed-out roads, making it challenging to provide assistance to those affected.
articles.title: Death toll from devastating floods in Libyan city passes 5,100

articles.description: Brazil has officially requested assistance from US law enforcement in investigations involving former President Jair Bolsonaro. This comes after Bolsonaro's ex-aide, Mauro Cid, agreed to cooperate with Brazilian investigators. The request aims to corroborate Cid's statements regarding his involvement in various criminal probes, including falsified vaccination records and the sale of expensive jewels. Bolsonaro, who denies any wrongdoing, is facing mounting legal troubles after losing his re-election bid.
articles.title: Brazil requests US help for probes involving Bolsonaro, sources say

articles.description: A fishing vessel owned by Greenland's government will attempt to free a luxury cruise ship that ran aground in northwestern Greenland. The passengers and crew on the stranded ship are reported to be safe and doing well. The scientific fishing vessel will try to pull the cruise ship free during high tide. articles.description:
Images taken by satellite show the physical devastation from a flood that killed at least 11,300 people in the eastern Libyan city of Derna. 

Two dams above Derna burst early Monday under the pressure from rain dropped by a storm. The pent-up water swept blocks of low-lying downtown Derna out to the Mediterranean Sea. 

Many said they heard loud explosions as the dams exploded. A flood several meters (many feet) high rolled down a mountainside into the city. 

Images made about 400 miles above the earthâs surface show that the storm left a brown layer of mud and dirt across the city.

Untold numbers are buried under mud and debris that includes overturned cars and chunks of concrete. The death toll soared to 11,300 as search efforts continue, Marie el-Drese, secretary-general of the Libyan Red Crescent, told The Associated Press by phone Thursday.

She said that an additional 10,100 had been reported missing. Health authorities previously put the death toll in Derna at 5,500.

The...
articles.title: AP PHOTOS: Satellite images show flood devastation that killed more than 11,000 in Libya

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish governmentâs earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response â waiting for aid and rescue teams â but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the disâ¦
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkeyâs bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy â and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russiaâs nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. âNearly every commerciaâ¦
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syriaâs deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. âIt was like the apocalypse,â Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last weekâs earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an uâ¦
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.Â  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOsâ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloonâs threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a âSputnik moment,â harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even warâ¦
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

The summit of Amazon Cooperation Treaty Organization (ACTO) members in the Brazilian city of Belem could agree to a regional pact to stop deforestation by 2030, end illegal gold mining, and cooperate on cross-border policing of environmental crime. Leaders are expected to announce the final agreement, known as the Belem Declaration, la...
articles.title: Amazon rainforest nations gather to forge shared policy in Brazil

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description: Georgian Prime Minister Irakli Garibashvili commemorated on Tuesday the victims of a brief war with Russia 15 years ago and lamented the loss of the breakaway regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia. "This was a terrible tragedy," Garibashvili said on the anniversary of the start of the South Caucasus war, which lasted from August 8 to 12, 2008. He said 400 Georgians were killed and more than 2,000 injured. To this day, Moscow supports the breakaway Georgian regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia and has stationed Russian troops in the region. Garibashvili said that the Black Sea republic was sti...
articles.title: Georgian premier marks 15-year anniversary of brief war with Russia

articles.author: Reuters UK
articles.description: By Boureima Balima and Abdel-Kader Mazou NIAMEY (Reuters) -Niger's junta on Tuesday rejected the latest diplomatic mission from West African countries aimed at restoring constitutional order after a July 26 coup, resisting pressure from the United States and the United Nations to come to the negotiating table. Heads of state from the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) are preparing for a summit on Thursday to discuss their standoff with the junta, which defied an Aug. 6 deadline to reinstate ousted President Mohamed Bazoum. ECOWAS defence chiefs agreed on Friday on a possible m...
articles.title: Niger junta rebuffs latest diplomatic mission as high-stakes summit looms

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description: Kia is clearly serious about offering a top notch electric and it has unleashed the plush EV9 to prove it. After achieving a degree of success with the EV6 two years ago, the Koreans have upped the ante with an imposing and well-equipped EV9, albeit it at a high price. The first lavishly equipped Launch Edition with all-wheel drive will bend your bank balance to the tune of â¬83,190 in Europe. Prices for the base version with no gizmos hover around â¬70,000. The snub-nosed EV9 is big but not brutish. It stands at 5 metres from bumper to bumper in length and is designed to lure SUV buyers as well...
articles.title: Kia hits the big time with Range Rover-beating electric EV9

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
London-based sex worker Marin Scarlett and right-wing populist Nigel Farage might initially appear unlikely campaigning allies, but when it comes to the pitfalls of banking in Britain they share a common cause.
"It's ridiculous that financial institutions can act like moral arbiters," Scarlett told AFP, echoing Farage's exact same criticism last month after a scandal erupted around his treatment by British banks.
Farage's complaints about the closure of his account with the upmarket Coutts, a subsidiary of NatWest used by the late Queen Elizabeth II, dominated the news for days, prompted questions in parliament and cost top executives their jobs.
For Scarlett, who is in her thirties and started out as a sex worker 15 years ago, the sudden uproar was galling, given arbitrary account closureâ¦
articles.title: 'Stigmatized': Sex workers join criticism of UK banks

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The second-ranking US diplomat met Niger's military leaders on Monday to press to reverse a coup but reported no headway a day after an ultimatum from the West African bloc ECOWAS was ignored.
Victoria Nuland, a veteran envoy and acting deputy secretary of state, said she met for more than two hours with military chiefs who ousted democratically elected Western ally Mohamed Bazoum on July 26.
Nuland's trip, conducted in secrecy until she left, came after the expiration of a deadline set by ECOWAS to reinstate Bazoum by midnight (2300 GMT) on Sunday or risk military intervention.
The 15-nation bloc is reconvening for its own diplomatic push on the crisis with a summit Thursday in Nigerian capital Abuja.
A source close to ECOWAS said an immediate military intervention to restore Bazoum was nâ¦
articles.title: US envoy meets Niger coup leaders but sees no headway

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Mourners and fans gathered Tuesday in the Irish town once home to singer Sinead O'Connor to pay their last respects ahead of her burial.
The musician's funeral cortege will pass along the seafront in the town of Bray, 20 kilometers (13 miles) south of Dublin, where she lived for 15 years.
The Grammy award-winning singer, best known for her cover of "Nothing Compares 2 U", died last month after being found unresponsive at her London home. She was 56.
The musician, who rose to international fame in the 1990s, will be mourned at a funeral attended by family and friends before a private burial.
Her family offered the public the chance to pay their final respects by organizing the cortege through Bray, saying she loved the town and its residents.
"With this procession her family would like to aâ¦
articles.title: Ireland bids farewell to singer Sinead O'Connor

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description:
ISLAMABAD (Reuters) â Pakistan's jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan appealed against his conviction and three-year sentence on corruption charges on Tuesday, his lawyer said, a ruling which analysts say is likely to fuel political instability. 
Naeem Panjutha said the petition challenging the weekend conviction had been filed in Islamabad High Court which will hear the case on Wednesday. Ex-cricketer Khan, 70, was jailed on charges of selling state gifts unlawfully during his tenure as premier from 2018 to 2022.
articles.title: Jailed ex-Pakistan PM Imran Khan challenges graft conviction

articles.author: Miami Herald
articles.description: As a kidnapped American nurse and her child marked their 11th day in captivity in Haiti on Monday, the United Nationsâ leading child-welfare agency says it is seeing an alarming spike in the abductions of women and children in the Caribbean nation. Nearly 300 cases have been reported in the first six months of this year, UNICEF said. The number is close to the total documented in 2022 and is close to three times more than what was recorded in 2021. In Haiti, most kidnappings are at the hands of armed gangs, whose warfare has worsened since the 2021 assassination of the countryâs president, Jov...
articles.title: Kidnappings of women, children spiking in Haiti where a US nurse, daughter remain captive

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: By Claudia Martini and Miguel Lo Bianco BUENOS AIRES (Reuters) - Argentines, who have seen jobs and wages hit by economic malaise and rampant inflation, lined up at churches on Monday to ask St. Cayetano, the patron saint of bread and labor, for employment, with some critical of politicians for not doing enough to help. The South American country, which saw unemployment tick up to 6.9% in the first quarter, is set for primary elections on Sunday where the conservative opposition is expected to outperform the ruling Peronist coalition. The run-up to the vote, in effect a dress rehearsal for the...
articles.title: Hard-hit Argentina workers ask saints, not politicians, for jobs

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Crouching beside Ukrainian-made attack drones on a runway, TV star Serhiy Prytula appeared keen to taunt Moscow with a crowdfunded fleet that experts have linked with recent strikes inside Russia.
Ukraine has not taken direct responsibility for the string of attacks, including on the capital Moscow, but President Volodymyr Zelensky has warned that "war" is coming to Russia.
Polls show the former stand-up comedian's crowdfunding campaigns for the military have rendered him one of the country's most trusted public figures -- second only to Zelensky.
Offering a rare glimpse at Ukraine's homegrown explosive drones, Prytula recently shared images of himself with a fleet in an undisclosed location.
"Muscovites! Shudder from the sirens. Go to the bomb shelters," he wrote on social media alongsideâ¦
articles.title: 'From Ukrainians without love': Drone fundraiser taunts Moscow

articles.author: Common Dreams
articles.description:
Local, national, and global leaders warned of the dangers of nuclear weapons as they commemorated the 78th anniversary of the dropping of an atomic bomb on the city of Hiroshima Sunday.
This year's anniversary comes as the release of the film Oppenheimer has offered a high-profile reminder of the history of the atomic bomb and as nuclear tensions in the current day have heightened, in part due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. At the start of the year, the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists moved their doomsday clock to 90 seconds to midnight.
"Leaders around the world must confront the reality that nuclear threats now being voiced by certain policymakers reveal the folly of nuclear deterrence theory," Hiroshima Mayor Kazumi Matsui said during his peace address at the commemoration ceremony â¦
articles.title: On 78th anniversary of Hiroshima bombing, mayor decries 'folly' of deterrence theory

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Organisers of the World Scout Jamboree asked host South Korea Monday to "urgently" evacuate tens of thousands of children from their campsite ahead of a typhoon, just days after a heatwave caused mass scout illnesses.
Typhoon Khanun, which killed at least two people in Japan, is due to make landfall in South Korea on Thursday, near where some 43,000 scouts have been camping in North Jeolla province for their problem-plagued jamboree.
Korean media have called the jamboree "a national disgrace" after an extreme heatwave caused hundreds of scouts to fall ill and prompted American and British scout groups to withdraw as criticism grew over conditions at the campsite.
Organisers had insisted the event would continue but on Monday the World Organization of the Scout Movement said Seoul had told â¦
articles.title: After heatwave, typhoon forces South Korea to evacuate scout jamboree

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
More than 3,000 US military personnel have arrived in the Red Sea aboard two warships, as part of increased deployments after tanker seizures by Iran, the US Navy said Monday.
The US sailors and Marines entered the Red Sea on Sunday after transiting through the Suez Canal in a pre-announced deployment, the US Navy's Fifth Fleet said in a statement.
They arrived on board the USS Bataan and USS Carter Hall warships, providing "greater flexibility and maritime capability" to the Fifth Fleet, the statement added.
The US military says Iran has either seized or attempted to take control of nearly 20 internationally flagged ships in the region over the past two years.
USS Bataan is an amphibious assault ship which can carry fixed-wing and rotary aircraft as well as landing craft. The USS Carter Hâ¦
articles.title: Thousands of US sailors, Marines reach Red Sea after Iran tensions

articles.description:
The UK government has revealed 80 prison officers did not attend their expected shift the day a terror suspect escaped.

Former soldier Daniel Abed escaped from a London prison strapped under a food delivery truck last Wednesday.

The government says despite the absent officers, overall staffing levels were still above the minimum requirement.

They maintain the numbers were not behind the security breach.

The absentee officers make up 40 per cent of the staff meant to be on shift.
articles.title: 80 officers absent the day prisoner escaped in UK

articles.description:
There are fears up to 20,000 people have died after flooding through eastern Libya. 

Hope is turning to despair for residents in the city of Derna as survivors continue to wade through the rubble in search of loved ones.

Questions are being raised about what could have been done to prevent the loss of life.

Satellite images from before and after the floods show the levels of immense destruction.

The hostilities in recent years have split the city into sections as rescue crews face a difficult task of bringing relief to as many places as possible.

articles.description:
At least 56 people, including children, have died in an apartment building fire in Vietnam's capital Hanoi.

Rescue efforts have been hampered due to the building not having emergency exits and being positioned at the end of a narrow alley.

At least 70 people were rescued and nearly 40 people were injured when they jumped onto neighbouring roofs to escape the inferno.

Firefighters extinguished the fire in about an hour, as footage shows the intense blaze shooting out from every floor of the building.

Vietnam's Prime Minister visited the site to extend his condolences and police have detained the building's owner ahead of further investigation.
articles.title: At least 56 dead following nine-floor apartment inferno in Hanoi

articles.description:
Former ADF personnel could face up to 20 years behind bars if they work for foreign military bodies without approval.

New legislation is set to be introduced by Defence Minister Richard Marles which will prevent sensitive defence information from being accessed by foreign militaries.

It follows revelations Beijing was seeking to poach former Australian pilots to train its military last year.

The Chinese recruitment scheme reportedly extended to using third parties for headhunting Western military leaders.  

Those working within the Five Eyes countries, the US, UK, New Zealand and Canada, will be exempt from the tough new rules.
articles.title: Tough new laws for unsanctioned ADF personnel working with foreign military bodies

articles.description: During COVID, many people discovered new hobbies, and that includes a Valley woman who started painting. That led her to a new passion and a new business venture. articles.description:
Reuters: China sanctions Northrop Grumman, Lockheed Martin for arms sales to TaiwanÂ 
BEIJING (Reuters) -China will impose sanctions against U.S. aerospace and defence firms Northrop Grumman and Lockheed Martin for providing weapons to Taiwan, the Chinese foreign ministry said on Friday.Â 
The sanctions are being enacted under China's Anti-Foreign Sanctions Law, ministry spokesperson Mao Ning told a regular press briefing.Â 
"We urge the U.S. side to effectively abide by the one-China principle... cease U.S.-Taiwan military liaison and stop arming Taiwan, or else it will be subject to a resolute and forceful retaliation by the Chinese side," she said. 

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
WNU Editor: We in the West are always reading and hearing reports on how the West is trying to decouple from China. What we do not read or hear about is China trying to decouple from the West.

Axios: Favorite Biden columnist: He "should not run again in 2024"Â 
President Biden, befitting his generation, loves newspapers and the classic columnists. David Ignatius, Tom Friedman and David Brooks top his list.

Â 
Driving the news: Ignatius, 73, a well-wired Washington Post foreign-affairs columnist who writes spy novels on the side, is out with a column (page A23 Wednesday) with the blunt headline: "President Biden should not run again in 2024."

Â 
Why it matters: Biden, 80, still sees himself as a young go-getter. Here's a respected voice he has known for 40+ years telling him that by plunging ahead, he "risks undoing his greatest achievement â which was stopping Trump."

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
Update #1: WaPo columnist argues Biden 'too old' to run again, should have stopped Hunter's 'attempts to impress clients' (FOX News)
Â 
Update #2: More Voices Call On Biden To Withdraw From The 2024 Race (Moon of Alabama)

Â 
WNU Editor: When you are a Democrat President and you lose David Ignatius. Yup .... you are in trouble.
Update #3: The poll numbers are certainly troubling (see below).

Just 28% of Americans think Biden inspires confidence, down 24% from two years ago or 7% from five months ago.
According to a CNN poll, only 26% believe "he has the stamina and determination to serve" as president pic.twitter.com/4lboXi09UK
â Sprinter (@Sprinter99800) September 10, 2023
articles.title: US President Biden's Favourite Columnist Says He "Should Not Run Again In 2024"

As predicted by a number of independent geopolitical commentators, including ourselves, the emerging official narrative on why Ukraine's counteroffensive ended in failure will be to falsely claim the West didn't provide "enough" weapons in a timely fashion. Despite the literally tens of billions of US taxpayer dollars sunk into Kiev's war effort at record-breaking pace and scale, it will be the "fault" of the United States and its alliesâor at least this will be solidified as the Ukrainian government's perspective and narrative (and then will be parroted among Zelensky's most diehard hawkish supporters).Â 
Read more ....Â 
Update: Zelensky Threatens To Terrorize Europe (Moon Of Alabama)

Â 
WNU Editor: Desperate people do desperate things. And they are some in Ukraine who are starting to grow more and more desperate. But to directly strike Europe if the West curtails their support? I doubt that this will happen.

Reuters: China becomes first to name new Afghan ambassador under TalibanÂ 
KABUL (Reuters) - China became the first country on Wednesday to formally name a new ambassador to Afghanistan since the Taliban takeover, after its envoy presented credentials at a ceremony in Kabul.Â 
The Taliban have not been officially recognized by any foreign government, and Beijing did not indicate whether Wednesday's appointment signaled any wider steps towards formal recognition of the Taliban.

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
WNU Editor: China has yet to formally recognize the Taliban government. But this is a first step towards a formal recognition by China that the Taliban are the legitimate rulers of Afghanistan.Â 
China Becomes The First Country To Send A New Ambassador To Afghanistan Since The Taliban Takeover

Taiwan's Kinmen is located adjacent to the Chinese city of Xiamen [File: Ann Wang/Reuters]

Al Jazeera: China unveils âspecialâ measures to boost Taiwanâs access to coastal Fujian

Â 
Beijing has proposed transforming Fujian province into a zone for integrated development with Taiwan.Â 
China will take a number of âspecialâ policy measures to improve access for Taiwanese enterprises to Fujian province across the Taiwan Strait, the Chinese state planner has announced, under a long-term cross-strait integrated development plan.Â 
China will deepen the integrated development of the Chinese city of Xiamen and Taiwan-controlled Kinmen islands, including the acceleration of gas, electricity and transportation links between the two, said Cong Liang, vice chairman of the National Development and Reform Commission, on Thursday.

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
WNU Editor: I lived and worked in this part of China in the 1980s. This is an idea that China (and some in Taiwan) have been pushing for decades.Â 
Update: Taiwan is saying no .... Taiwan rejects China's integrated development plan as politicised cash grab (Reuters).Â

The White House press pool is beginning to ask the right questions, and we can expect that these obvious inconsistencies will continue to dog the Biden campaign into the 2024 election.Â 
First, on Wednesday the White House's national security council spokesman John Kirby was at the podium and was appropriately grilled about why "the president lied about being at Ground Zero the day after the 9/11 attacks" among other falsehoods. "What is going on with the president? Is he just believing things that didn't happen did happen, or is he just randomly making stuff up?"

Â 
WNU Editor: The smirk on John Kirby's face when he is asked the question on President Biden's false narratives tells me that he really does not care what the media or public are concerned about when it comes to the President's lies. That in the end it will not make a difference. President Biden will still be re-elected in 2024.

LBC: âRussia expects this war to go on for some timeâ: North Korea meeting shows Putin âplaying long gameâ, ex-MI6 spy saysÂ 
Vladimir Putin's meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jon Un shows Russia is planning to "hunker down" for a long war in Ukraine, a former MI6 spy has told LBC.Â 
Speaking after Kim Jong Un arrived in Russia ahead of a meeting with Mr Putin, the former head of MI6's Russia desk told LBC's Andrew Marr there is "serious intent" behind the meeting.
"The Russians are now indicating they expect this war [in Ukraine] to go on for a long time and in fact, that may well be what lies behind their meeting with Kim Jong Un today," Christopher Steele told LBC. 

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
WNU Editor: Talked to my cousin who lives in Moscow last night. He has a lot of military experience, and his opinion is that this war is going to go on into 2026.
articles.title: Is Russia Expecting This War To Go On For Some Time?

Prague Monitor: Czechia Will Not Deport Ukrainian Deserters to KievÂ 
Ukraineâs attempt to extradite refugees who sought shelter in the Czech Republic to avoid conscription is expected to face significant hurdles through official channels. Such a request would likely contravene Czech law, making it impossible for Justice Minister Pavel BlaÅ¾ek (ODS) to approve it, as confirmed by the Justice Ministry to Echo24.
The Ukrainian military is currently launching a counter-offensive to regain territories occupied by Russian forces, requiring a substantial manpower. However, even amidst pervasive corruption, there remains a shortage of recruits. Some Ukrainian men have managed to evade military service by leaving the country with the assistance of bribes, potentially numbering in the tens of thousands.

Â

Zero Hedge: Trans Spox Says Ukraine Will Hunt Down "Russian Propagandists" Around The WorldÂ 
Sarah Ashton-Cirillo, the transgender ex-journalist from the US who is now a spokesperson for Ukraine's Territorial Defense Forces, has issued yet another bizarre and unhinged statement on behalf of the Ukrainian military.Â 
The military spokesperson is vowing that Russia's "propagandists" will be "hunted down" in a message which was published days ago, but which is now going viral and being mocked.Â 
Ashton-Cirillo said in the clip, "Next week, the teeth of the Russian devils will gnash ever harder, and their rabid mouths will foam an uncontrollable frenzy as the world will see a favorite Kremlin propagandist pay for their crimes."

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
WNU Editor: It is bad enough that everyone who is still in Ukraine must keep their negative opinions on the Zelensky regime to themselves or they may face certain consequences. But Kyiv's threats to now strike against those who voice a different opinion in another country is raising the conflict to another level. But what is even more disturbing is the "sound of silence" from Western governments and the Western media on these threats from the Zelensky government to attack citizens in another country.

articles.description:
DNYUZ/New York Times: Russia Overcomes Sanctions to Expand Missile Production, Officials SayÂ 
Russia has managed to overcome sanctions and export controls imposed by the West to expand its missile production beyond prewar levels, according to U.S., European and Ukrainian officials, leaving Ukraine especially vulnerable to intensified attacks in the coming months.Â 
In addition to spending more than $40 billion providing weapons for Ukraine, the United States has made curbing Russiaâs military supply a key part of its strategy to support Kyiv.Â 
As a result of the sanctions, American officials estimate that Russia was forced to dramatically slow its production of missiles and other weaponry at the start of the war in February 2022 for at least six months. But by the end of 2022, Moscowâs military industrial manufacturing began to pick up speed again, American officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to disclose the sensitive assessment now concede.

Â 
Read more ....

Â 
WNU Editor: So much for the Western political and media narrative that we have been hearing constantly for the past year that Russia was going to run out of missiles.Â 
On a side note.Â 
The above New York Times post reveals something that should give everyone pause ....Â 
Â .... it costs a Western country $5,000 to $6,000 to make a 155-millimeter artillery round, whereas it costs Russia about $600 to produce a comparable 152-millimeter artillery shell.Â 
Â You cannot win a war if the economies of production favors your opponent.
articles.title: Russia's Missile Production is Now Beyond Prewar Levels

Politico.eu: Shock and recriminations as Chinese spy scandal rocks UK parliament

Â 
Rishi Sunak under pressure to toughen stance on Beijing.Â 
Â LONDON â Rishi Sunak has spent most of his brief premiership treading a delicate balance on relations with China. So the last thing the British prime minister needed as he enters a careful autumn of diplomacy was a Chinese spy scandal erupting in his midst.Â 
Westminster is this week reeling from the news that a British citizen working as a parliamentary researcher for MPs is under arrest on suspicion of spying for Beijing.Â 
Two men, one in his 20s and another in his 30s, were arrested under the Official Secrets Act in March, police confirmed, after the news was reported in the Sunday Times. 

Â 
Read more ....

articles.description:
USAF

Â 
Warzone/The Drive: B-21 Raider Seen Like Never Before In New Images

Â 
We have just been given our first side view of Northrop Grummanâs B-21 Raider stealth bomber, an aircraft that remains cloaked in secrecy. Â 
During Air Force Chief of Staff Charles Q. Brown's speech at this year's Air & Space Forces Association's mega conference outside of Washington, D.C., the soon-to-be Chairman of the Joint Chiefs dropped two new images of the B-21 Raider. While the stealth bomber was rolled out in December of last year, it remains cloaked in secrecy. Brown, the top Air Force uniformed officer, didn't specifically reference the images in his presentation.Â 
Up until today, only one angle of the full aircraft has been seen by the public â head-on â and in a very controlled environment at the bomber's unveiling. Aside from a close-up of the cockpit area at an angle, all imagery published since then has been from the same head-on perspective, although it has progressively shown the aircraft in more detail. Now we have our first quartering view of the flying-wing jet, which provides significant details about its design. A new head-on image also gives us a better idea of the bomber's actual size. Both images were taken at Northrop Grumman's facility at Plant 42 in Palmdale, California. 

Â 
Read more ....Â 
New Images Emerge Of The B-21

Â

Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong Un are engaged in talks over North Korea's space program and the political situation in Asia and Europe. The visit is Kim's first with a world leader since Pyongyang shut down over COVID-19.Â 
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met with Russian President Vladimir Putin Wednesday for a day of talks that began at the Vostochny Cosmodrome in Russia's Far East.
The two leaders were at a remote Siberian rocket launch site, and began the day by inspecting a Soyuz-2 space facility.

articles.description:
BBC: Ukraine launches missile attack on CrimeaÂ 
Russia says Ukraine has launched 10 missiles and three unmanned boats in an attack on the home of its Black Sea fleet in Crimea.Â 
The attack caused a large fire at a Sevastopol shipyard which left 24 people injured, Russia said.Â 
Moscow-installed governor Mikhail Razvozhayev claimed most of the weapons were intercepted but that two ships had been damaged.Â 
Ukraine has strongly implied western-supplied cruise missiles were used.

They usually have built-in explosives and cameras that feed directly back to the person controlling them.
